Colin Green wrote:

>>But the idea of only adding a % of excess and disjoint genes I am 
>>unsure about.  If a complex of genes has formed that are all 
>>interdependent, that could be a bad move.  Maybe safer would be to 
>>just make adding *all* the excess and disjoint genes probabilistic.  
>>    
>>
>Good point.
>  
>
>>On the other hand, the real question of how to do it can only be 
>>addressed through comparisons of the types you've been doing, i.e. 
>>runs with one method vs. runs with another.  
>>
On the simple-ocr experiment there isn't much in it. The 
'all-or-nothing' approach (10% chance of getting all genes) performed 
slightly poorer than copying across 10% of all excess/disjoint genes. 
Also the population complexity rose to about 1000 in an hour with 
all-or-nothing versus 600. As I said before though, simple-ocr is 
probably artificially simple compared to most problems and will probably 
benefit from single connection genes being copied.

I'm going to try again with a different problem domain, but following 
Ian's comments and my previous emails it's looking like there may be 
room for some improvement in this area anyway.

Colin.
